ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: 2 hours
1-5 hours
Some weeks were more than others, especially gearing up for our trip, during and directly after.On average it would probably be aprox 4 hours.

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: Strengths: inter-graduate school collaboration with Forestry and IR students, practical application, hands-on work with a purposeWeaknesses: Not always the most efficient use of class time, would have liked more in-depth discussions about the readings
Strengths: trip to HaitiWeakness: we did not get to learn too much about sustainable development as a whole but more just about the country and culture of haiti

This class is a unique opportunity to work closely with professors and students from other graduate programs. Overall the class covered a wide range of topics from history to anthropology to forestry to public health, but Haiti was the always the underlying theme. This class is what you make of it, and you will miss out if you don't take full advantage of the diverse lectures, field trips, readings and other learning experiences it offers.

Strengths were the professors and TA - all were incredibly supportive and knowledgeable. They were encouraging and provided us with a wealth of knowledge about Haiti.The hands on experience of working with a client in Haiti was also a strength of the course, as well as the lectures that taught us about Haitian history and context of where we were working.

This course is excellent for Public Health Students with a global focus who are seeking to gain practical experience in the field. It also provides a great overview of health system strengthening, provision of care in limited- resource settings and program design.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Gordon Geballe  GREAT! Supportive and engaging and fun to be around
Instructor: Gordon Geballe  Dr. Geballe and Dr. Desir are two of the most friendly and funniest professors you will ever meet in your life.
Instructor: Gordon Geballe  Gordon and Gary were wonderful instructors and supportive mentors.

Instructor: Gordon Geballe  Gordon was always supportive of our work - he was constantly available for questions and willing to sit down to work with us on anything. His enthusiasm for the work was inspiring and he did an excellent job leading us throughout the course.

Instructor: Gordon Geballe  The instructor was excellent in guiding the participants in the class to be innovative in their thinking, practical and to understand the context in which there projects would be implemented.

narratives.question_text: If this course included instruction by a teaching assistant (TA), please evaluate the TA here. What are the strengths and weaknesses and how might their teaching be improved? (Specify name of the TA).
comments: Emily Dally did a phenomenal job organizing the class and especially the trip to Haiti. Everything ran smoothly because of her. She also had unique knowledge to share because she had spent the summer in Haiti.
Emily was diligent and hardworking, she organized most of the logistic details of the course and the trip
Emily was an incredible TA. She kept all of us on track in New Haven and in Haiti. She was responsive to questions and emails and knowledgeable about Haiti and the projects we were working on.

This class would not have been possible without the dedication and commitment shown by Emily. She was able to organize the trip, manage our groups, and acted as an incredible liaison between us and HAS. She was always available to work with us on projects and did an fantastic job throughout the course.

Emily was excellent as a TA. She has an in depth knowledge of Haiti, the hospital we worked with and the needs of the community. She was a great liaison between us and the hospital staff and also provide valuable feedback on our group projects.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Student consultancy for Hospital Albert Schweitzer - develop proposals that fit their goals
If you have to take one course at Yale, this is the course to go, the field trip to Haiti was absolutely one of the most amazing experiences of my life.

This course provides an amazing learning experience, but what you get out of it is largely dependent on the effort you put in. This class deals with real issues and the projects can have a real impact. Traveling to and working in Haiti was the highlight of the course, but the preparation before and group work after tie it all together.

Yes - I would recommend this course to fellow students. It was experiential learning and provided all of us with an opportunity to work on the ground and abroad - an opportunity most other courses do not allow. Thank you to the professors for making this possible!
Students interested in gaining practical experience in a global setting will really benefit from this class.
